a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I mean software that lets us run the tests across browsers and across OSes/platforms + a mechanism for collecting the results and storing them in a way that lets us generates reports of the results

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:48): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Like a javascript file that provides a set of functions for writing tests and (possibly) reporting the results (visually, to a harness, stc.)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:48): ah, I see

9ac93fad7c9a77617c9831c44389c55b (23:50): so it's a question of whether tests should be rewritten/required to do that, or introduce another layer is needed to extract the results
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:52): 9ac93fad7c9a77617c9831c44389c55b: For the HTML WG we seem, slowly, to be standardising around a single API for javascript tests

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:53): and then there will likely be a few visual tests for things that are inconvenient to automate

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:54): If we can keep it that simple, making a harness to read the results is quite easy, although actually auomating reftests in a cross browser fashion isn't really possible yet
9ac93fad7c9a77617c9831c44389c55b (23:54): what are reftests?

9ac93fad7c9a77617c9831c44389c55b (23:55): have you considered using any of the existing JS testing frameworks?
9ac93fad7c9a77617c9831c44389c55b (23:56): (for the js tests, obviously)
9ac93fad7c9a77617c9831c44389c55b (23:56): i.e. http://code.google.com/p/js-test-driver/ would give you a lot for free
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:56): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: No, no way to stop cascading.  You could set every property to explicit values, if you felt like.

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:57): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Yes, generally.  I am right now bodging a previously-developer harness into working just for the CSSWG so we can get impl reports in time.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (23:57): good to hear
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:58): But then I'll be writing one myself to work with the repo-slurper / review comment tracker I'm developing as well.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:58): I'm just being very slow at it, which is no good.  The sooner I finish it, the sooner I can start actually hacking on webkit.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:00): So, I'll be building a few harnesses.  First one is for self-describing tests, because they're the easiest.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:00): Then probably a js-test one using the framework that the testing WG is doing.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:00): Then reftest, if I can figure out how.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:00): "the testing wg"?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:01): Whatever you guys are.  I forget the name.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): oh the HTML test people?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): We kindof have a very basic harness the microsot contributed
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:01): I wouldn't be sad to see it replaced though
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:02): Well, you have some js functions that do test-y things that I can hook into.
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (00:02): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: ok. found an old thread were dean edwards proposed sandboxing styles like that but i guess it never ended up making it in.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:02): But there is also a html file that loads tests in iframes and allows you to mark the result
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:03): So what is that, a self-describing basically?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:03): I think it will hook into the js at some point in the near future
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:03): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb: Yeah. The feature set at the moment is pretty poor
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:03): e.g. for reftests if you can't actually provide automation (hard, requires proprietary APIs)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:04): you should at least provide a harness that allows you to view test, view ref, flip between the two, and mark the result
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:04): Right, reftests are a problem until we have dependable ability to draw DOM elements into canvas.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:04): Yeah, that's the limit of what humans can do right now.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:06): Mostly I don't think this is a big problem because vendors are working on their own reftest runners
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:06): Or have them already
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:06): Sure.  I think we all have the ability already, if we haven't built an actual runner for them.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:06): But you can't crowdsource a reftest runner.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:08): Well you don't really need to crowdsource, right? Or what do you envision crowdsourcing?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:08): Letting arbitrary people run tests themselves and report results.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:08): Like browserscope and the 20+ other similar efforts.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:09): The results are somewhat less trustworthy, but numbers can make up for that.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:10): It's not clear to me why it is interesting to do that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:10): I mean letting people run the tests is good for transparency
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:10): But should have rather little other value
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:11): Assuming that they are easy enough for vendors to run
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:11): (CSS2.1 tests fail here)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:11): Yeah, that's the thing.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:11): If you can't automate, then the time necessary to run them can be prohibitive.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:11): But ordinary people donating some time to it is easier.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:15): Yeah, that is a point
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:16): Really you want to avoid being in a situation where you are writing tests that vendors can't run economically
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (00:16): Sure.  That's why reftests were invented, to solve this problem for CSS.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:16): Because the value proposition to vendors of the tests is regression tracking
